{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3652042,"name":"Kyle Burman","username":"Flatop","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-12T23:56:26.457Z","cooked":"

Hey all, my team is looking into different control methods for swerve. Just last weekend at BattleCry we were using an upright joystick with up/down as forward/backwards, left/right for left/right, and twist for rotating our robot. We saw some teams doing it differently and are currently testing one joystick as everything but rotating and then one as forward/backward as rotating. We want to know what other people use for controls so that we might test them and see what is best for us.

We use an Xbox controller (so two joysticks) and we have the left one for translation (up is forward, right is right etc.), and the right as rotation (left and right for counter-clockwise and clockwise respectively)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-06-13T00:04:54.323Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":126,"readers_count":125,"score":90.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503110,"topic_slug":"swerve-control-methods","display_username":"Ezra","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62434,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5990 | Programmer, Electronics Lead, and Driver"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-control-methods/503110/2","custom_user_title":"5990 | Programmer, Electronics Lead, and Driver","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3652156,"name":"Owen Tharp","username":"Grumpy_Bud","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/e274bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-13T01:56:52.946Z","cooked":"

I think as of right now, there are a few main archetypes (for swerve driving specfically) I have seen for this game. This isn’t every control scheme, like the button board or reef tracking, as this is mostly for just how a driver controls the bot.

Single Flightstick: This is what our team ran for the main season. There are a few advantages to this, mostly being number of buttons. We had a control system to align to each side of the reef, and then buttons to refine it from there (left/right, height, etc). We had a button for each algae action as well. This meant higher level of complexity, but also controls felt less cramped and there was more room for freedom with plenty of override switches on the controller.

Single Xbox style controller: It seems to me that the main advantages of this control scheme is how easy it is for someone to pick up and start driving. The way it is set up just feels intuitive for basically anyone who has used a gamepad for video games. While button space is limited, our team has experimented with double presses and intelligent filtering for the algae button to be able to do everything as just one button.

I have also seen some unique ones, like using two flightsticks, almost like a giant gamepad with a huge amount of buttons. While it seems to me like that is a little overkill, there are teams who perform excellent with that.

In general, I think it comes down to these factors:

  1. Number of buttons: How complicated is the game? Do you have the software capabilities to simplify your controls with automations, or do you need more room? How much practice can you get your driver?
  2. Ease of use: The single gamepad setup our team has been working on is super easy for almost anyone to pick up and perform fairly well with. Because we have automations, we don’t need to take up multiple buttons for something like a climb sequence steps. This saves a bit of driver practice, but it doesn’t mean that it’s not important.
  3. Driver preference: Often, it could just be what a previous driver prefers. If they are familiar with a specific style of controls, why switch it up? Plus, you get to keep the controller from last year and get another backup.
